catalog.title: Principles of Comm
catalog.description: Introduces the study of communication in interpersonal, small-group, organizational, mass, and intercultural contexts; covers basic communication models, theory, and research methods used in communication.  This course is a controlled enrollment (impacted) course. Students who have previously attempted the course and received a grade other than W may repeat the course in the summer or winter; or only in the fall or spring semester with a petition to the College of Arts and Sciences Deans' Office.

catalog.title: Research Methods
catalog.description: Introduces the scientific methods used by communication scholars to examine interpersonal, small group, organizational, international/intercultural, telecommunications, and mass communication processes. catalog.title: Principles of Persuasion
catalog.description: Examines persuasive communication as a means of achieving goals and objectives. Also considers the theory and practice of influencing attitudes and opinions, particularly within persuasive campaigns.
catalog.subject: Communication

notes.note: : From suspenseful movies to binge-worthy TV to thrilling video games, people spend a lot of their leisure time with entertainment media. But what leads audiences to choose certain kinds of media content over others? Why do some audiences like specific content, while others hate it? And what are the effects of consuming entertainment media? In this class, we will endeavor to answer these questions by reviewing (A) the psychological processes underlying audiences' media selection decisions, (B) factors contributing to audiences' enjoyment of media, and (C) the cognitive and behavioral effects audiences may experience after consuming entertaining media. We will review classic theories of media entertainment and more recent empirical research targeted at understanding the relationship between audiences and entertainment media.

catalog.title: Spec Top in Mass Comm
catalog.description: Content varies each semester. Topics include television newscasting, mass communication and cultural studies, contemporary media issues, daytime TV/soaps, information systems, and communication technology.

catalog.title: Public Relations
catalog.description: Studies the role of the public relations practitioner as a specialist in communication, an analyst of public opinion, and a counselor to administrators. Also examines the function of public relations, and internal and external communication.

Students will design public relations plans for clients utilizing these or other new technologies.

catalog.description: Provides an opportunity for students to work in-depth on specific projects. A good basic understanding of public relations functions and terminology as well as excellent writing skills are musts.

catalog.title: Social Networks Analysis
catalog.description: Terrorist networks, telecommunication networks, computer networks, Facebook friends, Twitter followers--it seems that everywhere one looks, one finds networks.  Fundamentally, a network consists of a collection of actors and the connections amongst them.  Often the actors are individuals, but they can also be web pages, research articles, organizations, and nation states.  Each of us is embedded in a multitude of networks, connected to others by cultures, social relationships, and communication technologies.  Social Network Analysis is a collection of methods for analyzing these relational structures.  The emphasis is not on the attributes of the actors, but rather on the pattern of their connections.  Actors are defined not so much by their individual characteristics as they are by how they are related to others.  Focused as it is on the nature of the connections rather than the nature of the actors, network analysis is a perspective that cuts across the social, behavioral, and natural sciences.  It is one of the few truly interdisciplinary paradigms available today

notes.note:
Are smartphones making us stupid? Is screen-time bad for kids? Has technology ruined our ability to interact face-to-face with others? Is Instagram making us sad? Is Netflix making us lazy? Are media ruining our lives? 

Moral panic, or the fear that something will harm others¿ well-being, has ensued after the adoption of nearly every popular new technology. Just like some modern citizens worry that social media, video games, and screen-time will cause irreparable harm to vulnerable users, some historical citizens voiced concerns over the dangerous effects of comic books, radio, and even regular old books. 

In this course, we will examine the moral panic surrounding new technologies and modern media. We will read popular press articles that highlight the moral panic surrounding different media, discuss what is driving public concern on the topic, and then we will turn to science: What does science say about Netflix binges, social media trolling, and violent video games? Are people right to be concerned about their effects? How do we know? We will consider the positive and negative sides of media¿s role in our day-to-day lives, and look to see whether we can determine a net effect ¿ that is, all things considered, are media helping or hurting society at large? 

Drawing on research across the social sciences, the goal of this course is not only to consider scientific understandings of media¿s influence on society, but also to teach students the research and critical thinking skills necessary to consider similar big questions and seek out credible answers on their own. This course aims to foster media literacy skills that will benefit students throughout their college years and future careers.

catalog.title: UB Seminar
catalog.description: The three credit UB Seminar is focused on a big idea or challenging issue to engage students with questions of significance in a field of study and, ultimately, to connect their studies with issues of consequence in the wider world.  Essential to the UB Curriculum, the Seminar helps students with common learning outcomes focused on fundamental expectations for critical thinking, ethical reasoning, and oral communication, and learning at a university, all within topic focused subject matter.  The Seminars provide students with an early connection to UB faculty and the undergraduate experience at a comprehensive, research university.  This course is equivalent to any 199 offered in any subject.  This course is a controlled enrollment (impacted) course. Students who have previously attempted the course and received a grade of F or R may not be able to repeat the course during the fall or spring semester.
catalog.subject: Communication
catalog.requisites_description: Students who have already successfully completed the first year seminar course may not repeat this course. If you have any questions regarding enrollment for this course, please contact your academic advisor.
